title: Carmarthen Fans Walk Route

images.title: Nigel Davies / Llyn-y-Fan Fach
images.caption: Llyn-y-Fan Fach. The lake is actually a reservoir. This view is from the weir, looking around the horseshoe shaped walls of the dramatic Carmarthen Fans (Bannau Sir Gaer)

images.title: Alan Hughes / Bannau Sir Gaer
images.caption: Bannau Sir Gaer. The steep slopes of the Carmarthenshire Fans above Llyn y Fan Fach - viewed from the old red sandstone footpath that skirts the crests.

images.title: Cairn on Picws Du by John Light, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cairn on Picws Du

images.title: Picws Du from the east by John Light, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Picws Du from the east

images.title: Stuart Wilding / Below Picws Du
images.caption: Looking towards Pant y Bwlch from below the peak of Picws Du.

images.title: Shaun Ferguson / Fan Brycheiniog Summit
images.caption: Fan Brycheiniog Summit trig point and shelter

images.title: Stuart Wilding / Towards Twr y Fan Foel
images.caption: Towards Twr y Fan Foel

description: This walk climbs to Picws Du and Fan Brycheiniog in the Carmarthen Fans area of the Brecon Beacons Walks National Park. You can start your walk from the car park to the north of the hills. Then follow trails south to Llyn y Fan Fach before climbing to the Bannau Sir Gaer ridge. Follow the stunning ridge east and it will take you to the two highest points in the Carmarthen Fans at Picws Du (749 m (2,457 ft)) and Fan Brycheiniog (802.5 metres (2,633 ft)). At the eastern end of the ridge you can also visit the beautiful Llyn Y Fan Fawr .

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: For more walking ideas in the area see the Black Mountains Walks and Brecon Beacons Walks pages.
